title: The Impact of the International Right to Housing on National Legal Discourse: Using Data Science Techniques to Analyse Eviction Litigation
descriptions:
**Abstract:**

This project addresses the critical issue of eviction, a phenomenon that has profound implications for individual well-being and societal stability, particularly in the aftermath of the 2007-2011 financial crisis, which saw over 700,000 individuals in Europe at risk of losing their homes. The project focuses on the legal dimensions of eviction, exploring the interplay between national and international law, especially in the context of the right to housing as enshrined in international and European legal frameworks. National courts, tasked with adjudicating eviction cases, often find themselves navigating the tensions between domestic laws and the broader protections afforded by international law. This research aims to uncover the mechanisms through which international law influences national legal decisions, a question of increasing relevance amid growing national resistance to international legal norms.

By leveraging the extensive body of case law generated during and after the financial crisis, the project will employ a data-driven approach to analyze the impact of the right to housing on national legal outcomes. Using citation network analysis, the research will map the connections between international legal principles and their application in national courts, including both supreme and lower courts. Machine learning techniques will be applied to identify key predictors of judicial decisions, providing insights into how and why international legal norms are integrated into domestic legal reasoning. This innovative methodology, which combines legal scholarship with data science, has the potential to set a new standard for empirical legal research and could be extended to other areas of law, enhancing our understanding of the dynamic relationship between international and national legal systems.

**Description:**

Eviction – the involuntary loss of one’s home – has a devastating impact on people’s wellbeing and has severe consequences for society as a whole. During and after the financial crisis of 2007-2011, over 700,000 people in Europe either lost their homes or were at risk of losing them. National courts use national laws to rule on whether an eviction is just. However, the right to housing, as laid down in international and European law, often demands more protection of the power- and propertyless than national laws prescribe. As a result, national courts are at the centre of the complex interaction between national and international law. In times of growing national resistance towards international law, the questions whether, how, and why international law impacts on national law are among the most topical that legal scholars face. Evictions provide a timely opportunity to determine why international rights, such as the right to housing, may or may not have an impact on national law. The financial crisis has led to an enormous amount of case law (legal big data). The combination of the developed, but understudied, international right to housing and these vast amounts of national data offers a unique opportunity to examine the interaction between international law and national law. It is impossible to analyse all judgments manually. Therefore, I will use a data-driven approach that is unique in the legal discipline. Using citation network analysis, I conceptualise the right to housing as a network of international rights and conduct the first empirical analysis of the impact of this right in case law from national supreme courts and lower level courts. With the use of machine learning, I will identify predictors for courts’ decisions, and explain how these predictors may mirror the right to housing. This approach has long been called for but, so far, rarely been executed. If successful, it could be used in future research projects in other areas of the law.
